page.title: 01Farming Country On Exmoor
page.content: Three quarters of this land lies within Exmoor National Park. It is dominated by Shoulsbarrow Common, a moorland watershed over 450 meters high. Here is an iron age fort, Shoulsbury Castle, fenced in but not cultivated. Sheep are in evidence everywhere on the grassland, divided into small fields by beech hedges, planted on earth banks a meter high. Steep, narrow, twisting roads lead to isolated farms & one small village. A road, used as a holiday route lies on the Northern boundary. Behind are the high hills of Exmoor which shelter Challacombe, a village by the infant River Bray. An agricultural engineer has a repair business here. A farm now offers holiday cottages & campsite. The old school is for sale. No rector lives in the Rectory. It too is sold & now receives guests.
